If you do everything correctly and fast enough (there's a time limit in this task, too), you will see a window with a number. Submit this number as an answer for the task.

In this task, you will need to use the execute_script method in order to scroll the page to the visibility area of the elements overlapped by the footer.

task_list.name: working with files
task_list.description_text:
Uploading files

﻿In case we need to upload a file on a web page, we can use the already familiar send_keys method. However, instead of plain text, we now need to pass the file path as an argument.

To indicate the file path, we can use the standard Python module for working with an operating system — os. In such a case, your code won't depend on the operating system you are using. It will work with Windows, Linux, and even with MaсOS.

Here is a sample code that allows defining the path to the 'file.txt' file located in the same folder as the script you are launching:

import os 

current_dir = os.path.abspath(os.path.dirname(__file__))    # getting the path to the directory of the current executable file 
file_path = os.path.join(current_dir, 'file.txt')           # adding the file name to the path 
element.send_keys(file_path)

Now try adding the separate commands print(os.path.abspath(__file__)) and print(os.path.abspath(os.path.dirname(__file__))) to the file and see the difference. You can read about the os module methods on your own in the documentation: https://docs.python.org/3/library/os.path.html. Notice that that will only work when you launch the code from a file; it won't work in an interpreter.

In case you totally fail to understand what's going on, here's an example: 

Let's say we've written a script and saved it in lesson2_step7.py in our local folder D:\stepik_homework. Let's activate the virtual environment and launch  python lesson2_step7.py. Now, the  os.path.abspath(os.path.dirname(__file__)) command will return the path to the directory of the file with the code, i.e.,  D:\stepik_homework. Let's put the file we want to attach (file.txt) to the same folder.

file_path = os.path.join(current_dir, 'file.txt')

If we run the above command, the file_path  variable will contain the full path to the file 'D:\stepik_homework\file.txt'. An interesting thing is that if we move the files of  lesson2_step7.py together with  file.txt to a different folder or even to a computer with a different OS, the code will still work without any alterations.

 

The form element that looks like a file upload button has an attribute type="file". We must first find that element with the help of a selector and then apply the method send_keys(file_path) to it.

task_list.name: task_files
task_list.description_text:
Task: uploading a file

In this task, you will need to upload a text file in a registration form.

Write a script that will execute the following scenario:

  1. Open the page http://suninjuly.github.io/file_input.html.
  2. Fill in the text fields: first name, last name, email.
  3. Upload the file. The file must have the .txt extension and may be empty.
  4. Click the "Submit" button.

If you do everything correctly and fast enough, you will see a window with a number. Submit this number as an answer for the task.

task_list.name: alerts
task_list.description_text:
Alerts and how to deal with them

We've already come across alerts in our course when we got a solution number in our tasks. We also already know that we can trigger alerts with JavaScript:

alert('Hello!');
![](img.png)

Now, let's consider a situation where the test scenario requires not only getting the alert content but also clicking the OK button to close the alert. Alert is a modal window: the user cannot further interact with the interface until they close the alert. To do that, we first need to switch to the alert window and then accept it with the accept() command:

alert = browser.switch_to.alert
alert.accept()

To get the alert text, use the text property of the alert object:

alert = browser.switch_to.alert
alert_text = alert.text

Another kind of modal window, which offers the user a choice either to agree with the message or dismiss it, is called confirm. To switch to the confirm window, we use the same command as in the alert case:

confirm = browser.switch_to.alert
confirm.accept()
![img_1.png](img_1.png)

To dismiss the confirm window, we can use the following method:

confirm.dismiss()

It equals the user's clicking the "Cancel" button. 

The third kind of modal windows — prompt — has an additional field for entering text. To enter text, use the send_keys() method:

prompt = browser.switch_to.alert
prompt.send_keys("My answer")
prompt.accept()
![img_2.png](img_2.png)

task_list.name: task_alerts
task_list.description_text:
Task: accepting an alert

In this task, you need to write a program that executes the following scenario:

  1. Open the page http://suninjuly.github.io/alert_accept.html.
  2. Click the button.
  3. Confirm your agreement.
  4. In a new page, solve the captcha test for robots to receive the number answer.

If you do everything correctly and fast enough (there's a time limit in this task, too), you will see a window with a number. Submit this number as an answer for the task.

task_list.name: switching between tabs in browser
task_list.description_text:
Switching between browser tabs

When working with web applications, we sometimes need to use links that open in a new browser tab. WebDriver can only work with one tab. When a new tab is opened, WebDriver continues working with the old tab. To switch to a new tab, we need to indicate which tab we want to use. You can do that with the switch_to.window command:

browser.switch_to.window(window_name)

To find out the name of the new tab, use the window_handles method, which returns an array of all tab names. As we know that the browser now has two open tabs, we can choose the second one:

new_window = browser.window_handles[1]

We can also take notice of the first tab's name so that we can return to it later:

first_window = browser.window_handles[0]

After we have switched to a new tab, the search and the interaction with elements will proceed on a new page.

task_list.name: task_switching_windows
task_list.description_text:
Task: switching to a new tab

In this task, after you click the button, a page will open in a new tab. You need to switch WebDriver to the new tab and solve a problem there.

The implementation scenario is as follows:

  1. Open the page http://suninjuly.github.io/redirect_accept.html.
  2. Click the button.
  3. Switch to the new tab.
  4. Solve the captcha test and get the answer number.

If you do everything correctly and fast enough (there's a time limit in this task, too), you will see a window with a number. Submit this number as an answer for the task.

task_list.name: about modern web applications
task_list.description_text:
A few words about the modern web

Developers worked hard to ensure that in 2022, web pages would look neat and open quickly with the transitions between pages being almost unnoticeable. Site pages are interactive and instantly respond to the user's actions. In most cases, in order to implement such comfortable user experience, the Single-Page Application , which generally implies the existence of a single page on the site. Meanwhile, the content of the page is dynamically renewed by JavaScript, which quietly exchanges information with the server – for example, by means of REST API.

Everyone seems to be happy, only the authors of automated interface tests have a problem. Suddenly appearing and disappearing page elements, unpredictable time of page rendering, changing text in buttons and site messages — all these features of SPA applications need to be taken into consideration in automated tests, which, we have to admit, is one of the most difficult and challenging aspects of developing  automated tests in Selenium (as well as in other frameworks for writing end-to-end tests).

In this lesson, we will look in more detail at the most frequent problems and discuss ways of handling those.

task_list.name: about finding elements
task_list.description_text:
How get and find_element methods work

Let's consider one more WebDriver test – the one that checks the functioning of a button.

The test scenario is as follows:

  1. Open the page http://suninjuly.github.io/wait1.html.
  2. Click the "Verify" button.
  3. Check that the text "Verification was successful!" appears.

To open a page, we use the get method; then we find the required button using one of the find_element_by_ methods and press it using the click method. Then, we find the new text element and check that the text corresponds to what we expected.

Here's the automated test code:


from selenium import webdriver
from selenium.webdriver.common.by import By

browser = webdriver.Chrome()
try:
    browser.get("http://suninjuly.github.io/wait1.html")
    button = browser.find_element(By.ID, "verify")
    button.click()
    message = browser.find_element(By.ID, "verify_message") 
    assert "successful" in message.text
finally: 
    browser.quit()

Try launching the automated test. The test will crash with the message NoSuchElementException for the element with id="verify". Why does it happen?

Python commands are executed synchronously, i.e., in strict succession. The button search won't start until the get command completes. The button click won't happen until the button is found, etc.

However, tests will work smoothly only if the given web page does not use JavaScript (which is highly unlikely with modern web pages).
The get method waits till it receives the information from the browser that the page has been downloaded, and only then does our test start searching for the button. If the page is interactive, the browser will consider it downloaded, while the scripts downloaded by the browser will continue running. A script might control the appearance of the button on the page and, for example, display it with a time lag so that the button would emerge slowly and beautifully. In such a case, the test will crash with the already familiar error NoSuchElementException, as at the time of executing the command button = browser.find_element(By.ID, "verify"), the element with id="verify" won't be displayed yet. On that page, the pause before showing the button is set to 1 second, the find_element() method will make only one attempt to find the element and, in the case of a failure, will crash our test.

task_list.name: implicit waits in selenium
task_list.description_text:
Better solutions: Selenium Waits (Implicit Waits)

Hopefully, you've figured out that the solution involving time.sleep() isn't a good one: it is not scalable and is hard to support.

An ideal solution might be as follows: we need to avoid false test crashes due to the asynchronous work of scripts or server delays, so we will wait for the element's appearance on the page for a set time period (e.g., 5 seconds). We will check for the presence of the element every 500 ms. As soon as the element has been located, we immediately proceed to the following test step. Thus, in the ideal-case scenario, we will get the required element immediately, and in the worst-case scenario within 5 seconds.

Selenium WebDriver offers a way to set up such waits. It allows setting up a wait for driver initialization and applying it to all tests. It is called an Implicit wait, as we don't need to explicitly indicate it each time we search for an element – it will be applied automatically at the call of each subsequent command.

Let's improve our test with the help of implicit waits. To do that, we need to remove time.sleep() and add a line with the implicitly_wait method:


from selenium import webdriver
from selenium.webdriver.common.by import By

browser = webdriver.Chrome()
try:
    browser.implicitly_wait(5)
    browser.get("http://suninjuly.github.io/wait1.html")
    button = browser.find_element(By.ID, "verify")
    button.click()
    message = browser.find_element(By.ID, "verify_message")
    assert "successful" in message.text
finally:
    browser.quit()

Now, we can be sure that small delays in the site's work won't affect the stability of our tests. With each call of the find_element command, WebDriver will wait for the element's appearance for 5 seconds before throwing NoSuchElementException.

task_list.name: about exceptions
task_list.description_text:
Task: exceptions

Now we know how to set up waits in element search. While searching, WebDriver checks every 0.5 second whether the required element has appeared in the browser's DOM model (Document Object Model  is an "object model of a document", an interface for accessing the HTML content of the site). If an error occurs, WebDriver will throw one of the following exceptions:

  • If the element has not been found within the allocated time, we will receive NoSuchElementException.
  • If the element was found during the search but the DOM was changed at a later access attempt, we'll receive StaleElementReferenceException. For example, we found the Button element and in a while decided to apply the familiar click method to it. If the button got overlapped by the script over that time, there's no use applying the method — the element became "stale", and we'll see an exception.
  • If the element was found during the search but the element itself is invisible (e.g., it has zero dimensions) and a real user wouldn't be able to interact with it, we'll receive  ElementNotVisibleException.

Understanding the reasons behind the exceptions will help you in tweaking tests and locating bugs in programs.

Task:

What error will you see in the console if you try executing the browser.find_element(By.ID, "button") command after opening the page http://suninjuly.github.io/cats.html?

task_list.name: explicit waits and expected conditions
task_list.description_text:
Explicit Waits (WebDriverWait and expected_conditions)

In the previous step, we've figured out the problem of element waits on a page. However, the find_element methods check only the fact that the page element has been displayed. Meanwhile, the element might have additional properties that may be relevant to our tests. Let's consider the example with the button that sends data:

  • The button may be inactive, i.e., unclickable.
  • The button may contain text that changes according to the user's actions. For example, the text "Send" may turn into "Sent" after the button has been clicked.
  • The button may be overlapped by some other element or just be invisible.

If we want to click a button in our test and the button is inactive at the moment, WebDriver will still emulate the click but no data will be sent.

Let's try running the following test:

from selenium import webdriver
from selenium.webdriver.common.by import By

browser = webdriver.Chrome()
try:
    browser.implicitly_wait(5)
    browser.get("http://suninjuly.github.io/wait2.html")
    button = browser.find_element(By.ID, "verify")
    button.click()
    message = browser.find_element(By.ID, "verify_message")

    assert "successful" in message.text
finally:
    browser.quit()

We can see that WebDriver did find the button with  id="verify" and did click it, but the test crashed while searching for the element "verify_message" with the resulting message:

no such element: Unable to locate element: {"method":"id","selector":"verify_message"}

That happened because WebDriver quickly found the button and clicked it even though the button was inactive yet. In our web page, we intentionally set up a 1-second pause between the site loading and the button activation, but an inactive button at the moment of loading is a common thing in real websites.

To get a reliable test, we need to make it not only find the button on the page but also wait till it becomes clickable. To implement such waits, Selenium WebDriver uses the concept of Explicit Waits, which allows assigning a specific wait for a specific element. Explicit waits are set with the help of WebDriverWait tools and expected_conditions. Let's improve our test:


from selenium import webdriver
from selenium.webdriver.common.by import By

browser = webdriver.Chrome()
try:
    browser.implicitly_wait(5)
    browser.get("http://suninjuly.github.io/wait2.html")
    button = browser.find_element(By.ID, "verify")  
    # waiting for 5 seconds until button will be enabled
    button = WebDriverWait(browser, 5).until(
        EC.element_to_be_clickable((By.ID, "verify"))
    )
    button.click()
    message = browser.find_element(By.ID, "verify_message")

    assert "successful" in message.text
finally:
    browser.quit()

element_to_be_clickable will return the element when the latter becomes clickable; otherwise, it will return False .

Notice that the WebDriverWait implements the until function, which receives the wait rule, the element, and the value we will use in our element search. The expected_conditions module has many other rules, which allow implementing necessary waits:

  • title_is
  • title_contains
  • presence_of_element_located
  • visibility_of_element_located
  • visibility_of
  • presence_of_all_elements_located
  • text_to_be_present_in_element
  • text_to_be_present_in_element_value
  • frame_to_be_available_and_switch_to_it
  • invisibility_of_element_located
  • element_to_be_clickable
  • staleness_of
  • element_to_be_selected
  • element_located_to_be_selected
  • element_selection_state_to_be
  • element_located_selection_state_to_be
  • alert_is_present

You can find rule descriptions here.

If we want to check that the button becomes inactive after sending data, we can use a negative rule with the help of the until_not method:

# asking Selenium to proceed with checks for 5 seconds until the button becomes inactive
button = WebDriverWait(browser, 5).until_not(
        EC.element_to_be_clickable((By.ID, "verify"))
    )

task_list.name: task_waiting_for_text
task_list.description_text:
Task: waiting for the required text on the page

Let's now try to write a program that will make a vacation cabin reservation at a strictly defined price. Higher prices are unacceptable, while in the case of a lower price, the cabin will be immediately rented by someone else.

In this task, you need to write a program according to the following scenario:

  1. Open the page http://suninjuly.github.io/explicit_wait2.html.
  2. Wait till the cabin rent goes down to $100 (set the wait no lower than 12 seconds).
  3. Click the "Book" button.
  4. Solve a familiar arithmetical problem (use the previously written code) and submit the solution.

To find the moment when the rent drops to $100, use the text_to_be_present_in_element method from the expected_conditions library.

If you do it all correctly and fast enough, you'll see a window with a number in it. Submit this number as an answer for the task.

items.title: test_frameworks
items.custom_name: web application testing and test frameworks

task_list.name: manual vs automated tests
task_list.description_text:
Testing: automated vs. manual

To start writing good automated tests, you need to clearly understand the pros and cons of both automated and manual testing.

Manual tests Automated tests
Steps may be described in relatively abstract terms, A manual test may contain a step " Register a new user" without explanations how to do it; automated tests must clearly describe data, so the tester will be able to see new problems while following the test scenario and the registration scenario. Strict order and elaboration of steps. Only what has been included in the initial test scenario gets checked, so new errors in the product may be overlooked.
- Because of abstract descriptions of test steps, manual tests may sometimes give false-positive results: the expected result has been received but the tester has executed the scenario incorrectly and missed the bug.  + Automated test runs usually give the same results, as the scenario is defined accurately.
- Checking regression takes a long time, which results in the tester's tiredness and consequent errors due to lengthy monotonous work. + May be run on each commit of the application, which allows early error catching.

We also need to say a few words about the disadvantages of automated testing:

  • Possible test instability, which is not connected with the quality of the test itself but is rather triggered by external problems: unstable network connection, server problems, product code updates at the time of test running;
  • Automated tests require considerable time for developing and supporting.

Despite their disadvantages, in most cases, automated tests help to find errors faster and ensure the level of product quality. Automated tests allow optimizing testers' work and help to make users happy and – they can get new features in a shorter time and don't suffer from the errors in the product: developers quickly identify bugs and take measures to handle those without postponing the release of the product. Thus, automated tests help develop business by increasing the rate of implementing feature that bring profit.

In the ideal case, manual tests are run only at the stage of checking new features – it's a exploratory kind of testing, which allows finding problems in complex user scenarios.

task_list.name: testing pyramid
task_list.description_text:
Unit tests and integration tests

If you work with testing, you must already know the difference between unit tests and integration tests. Unit tests check a small fragment of code – usually, a specific function. In most cases, they are written by developers, who clearly understand the possible extreme cases in their tech stack. On the other hand, integration tests check the interaction of several systems. They may be written and supported by both developers or testers and analysts (in case they have a conveniently developed test writing framework).

Unit tests are always automated because they directly check code functioning. Integration tests may be both automated and manual. Sometimes, a separate category of end-to-end (е2е) tests is isolated – they check the whole tech stack of an application and the user's black box scenario of interacting with the application. As regards the UI tests developed with Selenium, they should be considered as end-to-end tests, as they check the joint work of all the systems of a web product: frontend and backend, databases, additional services like analytics, payment systems, etc.

We are not going to discuss the different test types in detail, but we recommend that you study the theory on your own. For example, here is an excellent and detailed paper: Test Automation Pyramid.

task_list.name: test structure
task_list.description_text:
Test structure

When writing UI tests, you can use the same Python features as in the case of unit tests created by developers. 

Any test should contain:

  1. Input data.
  2. A test scenario, i.e., a sequence of steps to be executed to get the result.
  3. Result check.

Let's discuss how we can do the checks.

task_list.name: expecting result in test
task_list.description_text:
Checking for expected result

How can we check for the expected result? We can use Python's built-in assert instruction, which checks the validity of statements. assert True does not result in the output of additional messages, while assert False will throw an exception: AssertionError.

Let's discuss the functioning of assert using an example with the built-in function abs(), which returns the absolute value of a number. First, activate the previously created virtual environment and run the Python interpreter.

Now, we'll be entering the below commands and looking at the results of execution.

If the expression value is true, there won't be any additional messages in the console. Let's try:

>>> assert abs(-42) == 42

If the condition has not been met, you'll see the error log in the console – with the name of the file, the number of the line where the error occurred, and the error type AssertionError:


>>> assert abs(-42) == -42

Traceback (most recent call last):

  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>

AssertionError

The plain message AssertionError is not very informative. When there are lots of tests, it may be difficult to remember what exactly we are checking in a given test. To add an additional message, you can call assert with the necessary message text after a comma; the message will be displayed if there's an error in the result checking:


>>> assert abs(-42) == -42, "Should be absolute value of a number"

Traceback (most recent call last):

  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>

AssertionError: Should be absolute value of a number

task_list.name: correct error messages
task_list.description_text:
Compound error messages 

Another thing we need to focus on is the quality of the error messages appearing when tests fail. Why is that important? A well-written text helps quickly locate the bug and figure out what has happened and why the test failed. A good assert will save you hours of work, especially when the number of tests is over a hundred.

Generally speaking, it's like with any feedback: it should be precise and timely. If you're checking for the presence of an element, make sure to write what kind of element it is: 

assert self.is_element_present('create_class_button', timeout=30), "No create class button"

Note: The is_element_present() function is auxiliary. Later we'll talk about how to realize and implement it.

If the element appears on several pages of the application, indicate where exactly the error occurred: 

assert self.is_element_present('new_announcement_button', timeout=30), "No new announcement button on profile page"

If you're working with some text (e.g., checking an information message, current URL, link, placeholder in an input element, or any other text), mention both values in the error message: the one you expected and the one you actually received. Like in a good bug report: the expected and actual result.

Formatting strings with concatenation

In Python, you can do that with concatenation, for example:

actual_result = "abrakadabra"
print("Wrong text, got " + actual_result + ", something wrong")

However, due to the abundance of quotes, pluses, et., that way is not really convenient and looks messy.

Formatting strings with str.format

A better option is shaping the text with Python's formatting features. You can read about it in more detail here: https://realpython.com/python-string-formatting/#2-new-style-string-formatting-strformat.

In short, Python can insert the user's values in strings with the help of the .format() function. The syntax looks as follows:

"Let's count together: {}, then goes {}, and then {}".format("one", "two", "three")

Try running it in the interpreter:

print("Let's count together: {}, then goes {}, and then {}".format("one", "two", "three"))

With code execution, such a string will turn into: 

Let's count together: one, then goes two, and then three

Thus, we can conveniently combine the expected and the actual values in one string.

Formatting strings with f-strings

Finally, the most up-to-date method of string formatting, which appeared in Python3.6, is called f-strings. It allows executing Python expressions right within the string and is even more concise and convenient. To use the features of  f-strings, prefix the string with the f symbol in the following way: f"your string {my_var}". In curly brackets, put the name of the variable, the value that must be used in the string, or the expression the result of which should also appear in the string.

You can read in more detail about f-strings here: https://realpython.com/python-string-formatting/#3-string-interpolation-f-strings-python-36. As we assume that you're using the latest Python version, we recommend applying that approach in our course.

Example 1:

str1 = "one"
str2 = "two"
str3 = "three"
print(f"Let's count together: {str1}, then goes {str2}, and then {str3}")

The result of execution in the interpreter:

Let's count together: one, then goes two, and then three

Example 2:

actual_result = "abrakadabra"
f"Wrong text, got {actual_result}, something wrong"

The result of execution in the interpreter:

Wrong text, got abrakadabra, something wrong

Example 3:

>>> f"{2+3}"
'5'

 

Another important thing: when you're working with the text of an element on a page or with any other content that may change, always write it into a separate variable for the sake of comparison. 

Incorrect: 

assert self.catalog_link.text  == "Catalog", \
    f"Wrong language, got {self.catalog_link.text} instead of 'Catalog'"

It's a bad practice to read an attribute twice because the text on the page may change by the second reading and you will receive an irrelevant error text. It's hard to analyze the result of such a test: 

"Wrong language, got 'Catalog' instead of 'Catalog'"

Correct: 

catalog_text = self.catalog_link.text # reading the text and writing it into a variable
assert catalog_text == "Catalog", \
    f"Wrong language, got {catalog_text} instead of 'Catalog'"

task_list.name: task_messages
task_list.description_text:
Task: compound error messages

To solidify what you have learned, implement a check by yourself. 

You are given a function test_input_text, which takes two values: expected_result — the expected result, and actual_result — the actual result. Notice that you don't need to use input!

The function needs to check that the values match with the help of the assert operator and, in the case of a mismatch, provide a comprehensive error message. 

Important! The format of the error should exactly match that in the example so that the checking system accepts it! 

You don't need to handle the situation with empty or invalid input. 

Sample Input 1: 8 11 Sample Output 1: expected 8, got 11

task_list.name: task_message_errors_substring
task_list.custom_name: task: correct error messages with substrings
task_list.description_text:
Task: compound error messages and substring search

Sometimes when working with texts, we do not need strict checks for exact matching – instead, we just need to check that a certain text is a substring of another text. We can do that either with the in key word or with the find function:

s = 'My Name is Julia'

if 'Name' in s:
    print('Substring found')

index = s.find('Name')
if index != -1:
    print(f'Substring found at index {index}')

Try running that code in the interpreter to see the difference in the two approaches.

The 'Name' in s construct returns just True or False, while find() returns the index of the first occurrence of the substring in the string; otherwise, if the substring has not been found, it returns -1. In most cases, it's sufficient to use in in automated tests because of better readability.

For example, we can check that the current URL contains the string login: 

assert "login" in browser.current_url, # error message

Implement such a check yourself. 

You are given a template for the test_substring function, which receives two values: full_string and substring. 

The function needs to check for the occurrence of the substring in the full_string with the help of the assert operator and, in the case of a mismatch, provide a comprehensive error message. 

Important! The format of the error should exactly match that in the example so that the checking system accepts it! 

You don't need to handle the situation with empty or invalid input.

task_list.name: how to run test cases
task_list.description_text:
Test scenarios

You need to save the created tests in a file, which is easy to run and keep in a version control system. Let's create a file test_abs_project.py and write the following code in it:

def test_abs1():
    assert abs(-42) == 42, "Should be absolute value of a number" 

if __name__ == "__main__":
    test_abs1()
    print("All tests passed!")

We put the test scenario into a function to separate test cases and run them independently.

Without going into details, we'll just say that the if __name__ == "__main__" construct is designed to confirm that the script was run directly rather than called within another file as a module. All the code in the body of this condition will be executed only if the user has run the file themselves. You can find more details about it in Oleg Molchanov's video. 

In that construct, we called the test_abs1() function, which executes the test scenario.

With the help of print("All tests passed!"), we output a message if all tests pass successively.

To run the test, execute the following command in the console:

python test_abs_project.py

In the console, you will see the message "All tests passed!"

 

If we need to add one more test, we can write it as a function in the same file. In the above example, we won't see the message "Everything passed" anymore, as any test's failure leads to exiting the program:

def test_abs1():
    assert abs(-42) == 42, "Should be absolute value of a number"

def test_abs2():
    assert abs(-42) == -42, "Should be absolute value of a number"

if __name__ == "__main__":
    test_abs1()
    test_abs2()
    print("Everything passed")

Run the file again. You will see a message about the second test's failure:


$ python test_abs_project.py

Traceback (most recent call last):

  File "test_abs_project.py", line 9, in <module>

    test_abs2()

  File "test_abs_project.py", line 5, in test_abs2

    assert abs(-42) == -42, "Should be absolute value of a number"

AssertionError: Should be absolute value of a number

task_list.name: about test runners
task_list.description_text:
Choosing a test runner

In the previous steps, we've learned to write simple tests and run them with Python. Let's remember the test code and the results of test running from the previous step.

test_abs_project.py:

def test_abs1():
    assert abs(-42) == 42, "Should be absolute value of a number"

def test_abs2():
    assert abs(-42) == -42, "Should be absolute value of a number"

if __name__ == "__main__":
    test_abs1()
    test_abs2()
    print("Everything passed")

Console:


$ python test_abs_project.py

Traceback (most recent call last):

  File "test_project.py", line 9, in <module>

    test_abs2()

  File "test_project.py", line 5, in test_abs2

    assert abs(-42) == -42, "Should be absolute value of a number"

AssertionError: Should be absolute value of a number

Let's look at the drawbacks of such an approach to test running:

  • When the number of tests gets large, it becomes difficult to run the tests only from the necessary test suites.
  • For each test, we need to create separate test data and an environment. For example, if we want to start the browser for each test and then close it after completing the test, we'll need to duplicate that logic in the code of each test.
  • If one of the tests finishes with an error (for example, a test will fail with AssertionError), the subsequent tests won't run. We can't know if there were problems in those tests until we fix the failed test or run the remaining tests separately.

To solve these problems and to facilitate test writing and running, there are special frameworks called test runners. We can mention three major test frameworks for Python: unittest, PyTest, and nose. The unittest module is a built-in Python tool — and that is its great advantage. PyTest and nose are installed separately, and compared with unittest, they allow more opportunities. We'll take a brief look at the use of unittest and then study the features of PyTest, which allows writing simpler test code compared with unittest and flexibly setting up test running. Another advantage of PyTest is that there are more plugins written for it – they allow solving practically any problem connected with running automated tests.

task_list.name: about unittest
task_list.description_text:
unittest

Test runners can find test methods in the files defined at the test start; however, to ensure that, we need to follow common rules. Here is a common rule for all frameworks: the name of a test method must start with the word "test_".  What follows is any text – the unique name of the test:

def test_name_for_your_test():

unittest also has its own additional rules:

  • Tests need to be located in a special test class.
  • Instead of assert, we need to use special assertion methods.

Now, let's modify our previous tests so that we can run them with unittest. We'll need to execute the following steps:

  1. Import unittest into a file: import unittest.
  2. Create a class that inherits from the TestCase class: class TestAbs(unittest.TestCase):.
  3. Turn test functions into methods by adding a reference to a class copy self as the first argument of the function: def test_abs1(self):.
  4. Change assert to self.assertEqual().
  5. Change the command of running the program to unittest.main().
import unittest

class TestAbs(unittest.TestCase):
    def test_abs1(self):
        self.assertEqual(abs(-42), 42, "Should be absolute value of a number")
        
    def test_abs2(self):
        self.assertEqual(abs(-42), -42, "Should be absolute value of a number")
        
if __name__ == "__main__":
    unittest.main()

After all the changes, let's run the file with the tests using Python:

python test_abs_project.py

.F

======================================================================

FAIL: test_abs2 (__main__.TestAbs)

----------------------------------------------------------------------

Traceback (most recent call last):

  File "test_abs_project.py", line 9, in test_abs2

    self.assertEqual(abs(-42), -42, "Should be absolute value of a number")

AssertionError: Should be absolute value of a number

----------------------------------------------------------------------

Ran 2 tests in 0.000s

FAILED (failures=1)

Now we see more detailed information about the results of the run: two tests were run, one test threw an error. The location of the error and comments on it are shown in the log.

In the following lesson, we'll consider the advantages and features of using the PyTest test framework. If you want to use unittest in your tests, you can study the documentation on your own.

task_list.name: task_unittest
task_list.description_text:
Task: writing tests in the unittest style

Try to rewrite the tests from the first module in the unittest style.

Take the [step](course://introduction/finding_elements_selenium/task10) from the first section and rewrite your tests in the unittest style.
  • In test.py, create a class with tests which will inherit from unittest.TestCase like in the previous step.
  • Rewrite the test for the page http://suninjuly.github.io/registration1.html in the unittest style.
  • Rewrite the second test for the page http://suninjuly.github.io/registration2.html in the unittest style.
  • Format the final checks in the tests in the unittest style: for example, use the assertEqual method.
  • Run the tests.
  • Look through the test report and find the last line.
Insert the line into [answer.txt](file://test_frameworks/test_frameworks/task_unittest/answer.txt).

Notice that the second test is supposed to throw NoSuchElementException. If you use the try/except construct, you need to run the test without it here. You don't need to catch exceptions (at least, in this case)!

All that is supposed to illustrate that unittest will execute tests and summarize the results even if an unexpected exception is thrown. 

Do not delete your code after completing the task – you will need it in the following lesson.

task_list.name: pytest_pros_cons
task_list.description_text:
PyTest — pros and cons

Additional links: https://realpython.com/pytest-python-testing/ https://www.guru99.com/pytest-tutorial.html

Let's consider the advantages of using PyTest:

1) PyTest is fully backwards compatible with the unittest and nosetest frameworks. That means that if you initially wrote your tests using unittest, you can instantly switch to PyTest. To do that, make sure that the PyTest package is installed in your virtual environment. Don't forget to activate your virtual environment and install PyTest.

In Windows:

> selenium_env\Scripts\activate.bat 
(selenium_env) С:\Users\user\environments>  pip install pytest==7.1.2

In Linux and macOS:

​​​​​​​$ source selenium_env/bin/activate 

(selenium_env) $ pip install pytest==7.1.2

Now we can run the tests in our test_abs_project.py file with PyTest without modifying the file. PyTest will find the tests in the folder you run them from and will execute them:

pytest test_abs_project.py

2) A detailed report supporting color schemes out of the box.

3) Unlike unittest, PyTest does not require writing additional specific constructs in test (no boilerplate).

4) Python's standard assert is used in checks.

5) It's possible to create dynamic fixtures (special functions setting up test environments and prepare test data).

6) Additional features in setting up fixtures.

7) Test parametrization – you can set up different parameters for the same test (the test will be run several times with different test data).

8) Availability of marks, which marking tests for selective launching.

9) Possibility to pass additional parameters in the command line to set up test environments.

10) A large number of plugins, which expand the capacity of PyTest and allow solving specific problems and save time.

Let's look at the disadvantages of PyTest:

1) Unlike unittest, PyTest is not included in Python's standard library package and has to be installed separately. Don't forget about that when you set up automated test runs with the CI server.


2) The use of PyTest requires a deeper understanding of Python, which is needed, for example, in applying fixtures, parametrization, and other PyTest features.

task_list.name: pytest_rules
task_list.description_text:
PyTest: rules of test running

In this step, we will briefly discuss several important aspects of running tests with PyTest. When we execute the pytest command, the test runner collects all the tests to be run according to specific rules:

  • If we don't pass any arguments in the command and simply type pytest, the test runner will start looking for tests in the current directory.

  • We can pass a file, directory path, or any combination of directories and files as an argument, for example: 

pytest scripts/selenium_scripts
# find all tests in the directory scripts/selenium_scripts

pytest test_user_interface.py
# find and run all tests in a file

pytest scripts/drafts.py::test_register_new_user_parametrized
# find the test named test_register_new_user_parametrized in the specified file in the specified directory and run it

  • Then PyTest proceeds to recursive search: it will go through all nested directories.

  • In all the directories, PyTest looks for files that satisfy the rule test_*.py or *_test.py (i.e., start with test_ or end with _test and have the .py extension).

  • In all these files, PyTest finds test functions according to the following rule:

    • all the tests with names starting with test that are located outside classes

    • all the tests with names starting with test inside classes классов with names starting with Test (and without the __init__ method within the class)

Details: Conventions for Python test discovery

task_list.name: test_run_task
task_list.description_text:
Task: running tests

An applicant sent a testing project as a test task for a vacancy in your company: 

The content of the files looks like this: 

tests_for_pytest/test_main_page: 

# номер 1
def main_page_buttons(browser):

# номер 2
def test_main_page_navbar(browser):

smoke_tests/login.py:

# номер 3

# номер 4
class TestLogin(object):
    def test_guest_should_see_login_link(self, browser, language):

(the root directory of the project) test_regression.py:

class TestLessonCreate():
    # номер 5
    def test_create_lesson(self, browser):

    # номер 6
    def user_with_lesson_can_create_lesson_from_navbar_test(self, browser):


class CourseCreate():
    # номер 7
    def test_create_course(self, browser):

# номер 8
def test_guest_can_open_new_course(browser):

You are trying to run the tests from the directory with the test_project using a PyTest command: 

pytest test_project

Mark only those test methods that PyTest will find and execute:

task_list.name: reporting in pytest
task_list.description_text:
PyTest — reports

You might have noticed that PyTest allows generating a detailed report supporting color schemes and formatting right out of the box.

Let's run our tests with unittest and PyTest once again and compare the outputted result.

We can see that in the PyTest report, the failed test is highlighted with a red font, which facilitates the process of log analysis.

unittest:

PyTest: 

If we run PyTest with the parameter -v (verbose), the report will be supplemented with additional information – the list of tests and their execution statuses: 

You can find other commands for manipulating the output of PyTest tests here: Useful py.test commands.

task_list.name: pytest style of test cases
task_list.description_text:
PyTest — how to write tests

Unlike unittest, PyTest does not require writing additional specific constructs in tests.

We've already seen that PyTest can run tests written in the unittest style. Let's rewrite our tests from test_abs_project.py in a simpler format, which is also understood by PyTest. Let's name the new file test_abs.py:

def test_abs1():
    assert abs(-42) == 42, "Should be absolute value of a number"

def test_abs2():
    assert abs(-42) == -42, "Should be absolute value of a number"

Let's run the tests in the file:

pytest test_abs.py

Test code has become more concise and readable.

task_list.name: assertion in pytest
task_list.description_text:
PyTest — checking the expected result (assert)

If you're working with unittest to check the expected test results, you need to know and use a large number of assert methods: for example, assertEqual, assertNotEqual, assertTrue, assertFalse, and others.

PyTest uses the standard Python's assert method, which makes code more explicit.

Let's compare two approaches and check that two variables are equal.

unittest:

self.assertEqual(a, b, msg="Values differ")

PyTest:

assert a == b, "Values differ"

With the help of assert, we can check any construct that returns True/False. It may be equality or inequality checks, occurrence of a substring in a string, or any other auxiliary function that you describe yourselves. All that makes the test code clear and readable: 

assert user_is_authorised(), "User is guest"

If we need to check that our test triggers the expected exception (which is a rare situation in UI testing, and most probably you won't ever need it), we can use a special construct with pytest.raises(). For example, we can check that a site page doesn't display a certain element:

import pytest

from selenium import webdriver
from selenium.webdriver.common.by import By
from selenium.common.exceptions import NoSuchElementException


def test_exception1():
    try:
        browser = webdriver.Chrome()
        browser.get("http://selenium1py.pythonanywhere.com/")
        with pytest.raises(NoSuchElementException):
            browser.find_element(By.CSS_SELECTOR, "button.btn")
            pytest.fail("Should be no 'Submit' button")
    finally: 
        browser.quit()

def test_exception2():
    try:
        browser = webdriver.Chrome()
        browser.get("http://selenium1py.pythonanywhere.com/")
        with pytest.raises(NoSuchElementException):
            browser.find_element(By.CSS_SELECTOR, "no_such_button.btn")
            pytest.fail("Should be no 'Submit' button")
    finally: 
        browser.quit()

In the first test, the element will be found, so the NoSuchElementException error expected by the pytest.raises context manager won't be thrown and the test will fail.

test_3_3_9_pytest_raises.py:8 (test_exception1)
E   Failed: Should be no 'Submit' button

In the second case, as we expected, the button won't be found and the test will pass.

task_list.name: classic fixtures
task_list.description_text:
Classic fixtures

An important aspect of working with PyTest is the concept of fixture. In the context pf PyTest, fixtures are auxiliary functions that are not part of the test scenario..

The purposes of fixtures may be different. One of the most popular uses of fixtures is preparing the test environment and cleaning up the test environment and data after test completion. However, fixtures may be used for a wide range of purposes: connecting to a database the tests work with, creating test files, or preparing data in the current environment with the help of API methods. You can read about fixtures in the general sense in more detail in Wikipedia.

A classic way of working with fixtures is creating setup and teardown methods in a file with tests (PyTest documentation).

We can create fixtures for modules, classes, and separate functions. Let's try to write a fixture for browser initialization, which we can later use in our tests. After test completion, we will automatically close the browser with the browser.quit() command to avoid having a number of open browser windows in our system. We'll leave browser initializing and closing to fixtures so that we don't need to write that code for each test.

We'll start combining our tests into test suites; classes will function as suites in which we store our tests.

Let's consider two examples: creating a copy of a browser and closing it once for all the tests of the first test suite, and creating a browser for each test of the second test suite. Save the below code in the file test_fixture1.py  and run it with PyTest. Don't forget to indicate the parameter -s to see the text displayed by the print() command.

pytest -s test_fixture1.py

test_fixture1.py:

from selenium import webdriver
from selenium.webdriver.common.by import By
link = "http://selenium1py.pythonanywhere.com/"


class TestMainPage1():

    @classmethod
    def setup_class(self):
        print("\nstart browser for test suite..")
        self.browser = webdriver.Chrome()

    @classmethod
    def teardown_class(self):
        print("quit browser for test suite..")
        self.browser.quit()

    def test_guest_should_see_login_link(self):
        self.browser.get(link)
        self.browser.find_element(By.CSS_SELECTOR, "#login_link")

    def test_guest_should_see_basket_link_on_the_main_page(self):
        self.browser.get(link)
        self.browser.find_element(By.CSS_SELECTOR, ".basket-mini .btn-group > a")


class TestMainPage2():

    def setup_method(self):
        print("start browser for test..")
        self.browser = webdriver.Chrome()

    def teardown_method(self):
        print("quit browser for test..")
        self.browser.quit()

    def test_guest_should_see_login_link(self):
        self.browser.get(link)
        self.browser.find_element(By.CSS_SELECTOR, "#login_link")

    def test_guest_should_see_basket_link_on_the_main_page(self):
        self.browser.get(link)
        self.browser.find_element(By.CSS_SELECTOR, ".basket-mini .btn-group > a")

In the console, we see:  

We see that in the first test suite, the browser was launched once, while in the second one – twice.

The data and the cash left from the previous test run may affect the results of subsequent tests, so it's a good idea to launch a separate browser for each test to ensure test stability. Besides, if the browser suddenly hangs in one of the tests, the rest of the tests won't be affected if they are run in a separate browser each.

The disadvantages of launching a browser for each test are the following: opening and closing the browser takes time, so your tests will be longer. You may want to optimize the time of the test run, but it's better to do that with other tools, which we will discuss later.

Usually, such fixtures migrate together with tests written with unittest, and we need to support them. However, everybody now writes more flexible fixtures @pytest.fixture, which we will discuss in the next step.

task_list.name: fixtures returning value
task_list.description_text:
Fixtures returning a value

We've discussed the basic approach to creating fixtures, with test data being set up and cleaned up in the setup and teardown methods. PyTest offers an advanced approach to fixtures, within which fixtures may be defined globally and passed to test methods as parameters; besides, there is a set of built-in fixtures. It's a more flexible and convenient way of working with auxiliary functions, and now you will see why. 

Returned value

Fixtures may return a value, which may be later used in tests. Let's rewrite our previous example with PyTest fixtures. We'll create a browser fixture, which will create a WebDriver object. We will be able to use that object in tests to interact with the browser. To do that, we'll write a browser method and will indicate that it is a fixture with the help of the @pytest.fixture decorator. After that, we'll be able to call the fixture in tests by passing it as a parameter.By default, the fixture will be created for each test method,i.e., for each test there will be a separate browser copy.

pytest -s -v test_fixture2.py

test_fixture2.py:

import pytest
from selenium import webdriver
from selenium.webdriver.common.by import By

link = "http://selenium1py.pythonanywhere.com/"


@pytest.fixture
def browser():
    print("\nstart browser for test..")
    browser = webdriver.Chrome()
    return browser


class TestMainPage1():
    # вызываем фикстуру в тесте, передав ее как параметр
    def test_guest_should_see_login_link(self, browser):
        browser.get(link)
        browser.find_element(By.CSS_SELECTOR, "#login_link")

    def test_guest_should_see_basket_link_on_the_main_page(self, browser):
        browser.get(link)
        browser.find_element(By.CSS_SELECTOR, ".basket-mini .btn-group > a")

task_list.name: finalizing fixtures
task_list.description_text:
Finalizers — closing the browser

You may have noticed that in our example we didn't use the browser.quit() command. As a result, several browser windows remained open after the test was over and closed only after the completion of all tests. The browsers were closed thanks to a built-in fixture – garbage collector. However, if we had several dozens of tests, the open browser windows could have eaten all RAM. That's why it's important to explicitly close browsers after each test. To do that, we can use finalizers. One of possible finalizers is the use of Python's key word yield. After the test that called the fixture is complete, the fixture will be executed starting with the line that follows the line with the yield word:

test_fixture3.py

import pytest
from selenium import webdriver
from selenium.webdriver.common.by import By

link = "http://selenium1py.pythonanywhere.com/"


@pytest.fixture
def browser():
    print("\nstart browser for test..")
    browser = webdriver.Chrome()
    yield browser
    # this code will run after the test is completed
    print("\nquit browser..")
    browser.quit()


class TestMainPage1():
    # calling the fixture in the test by passing it as a parameter
    def test_guest_should_see_login_link(self, browser):
        browser.get(link)
        browser.find_element(By.CSS_SELECTOR, "#login_link")

    def test_guest_should_see_basket_link_on_the_main_page(self, browser):
        browser.get(link)
        browser.find_element(By.CSS_SELECTOR, ".basket-mini .btn-group > a")

There's an alternative way to call the teardown code – with the built-in request fixture and its method addfinalizer. You can study it on your own in the PyTest documentation. 

We also recommend leaving data and memory cleaning up to the fixture instead of writing it in test steps: the finalizer will be executed even when the test fails with an error.

task_list.name: fixture scopes
task_list.description_text:
Scope

For fixtures, we can define scope. The possible values are: “function”, “class”, “module”, and “session”. Consequently, the fixture will be executed once for a test method, once for a class, once for a module, or once for all the tests run in the current session. 

Let's run all our tests from the TestMainPage1 class in one browser to save time. In the browser fixture, we'll set scope="class":

test_fixture5.py

import pytest
from selenium import webdriver
from selenium.webdriver.common.by import By

link = "http://selenium1py.pythonanywhere.com/"


@pytest.fixture(scope="class")
def browser():
    print("\nstart browser for test..")
    browser = webdriver.Chrome()
    yield browser
    print("\nquit browser..")
    browser.quit()


class TestMainPage1():

    # calling the fixture in the test by passing it as a parameter
    def test_guest_should_see_login_link(self, browser):
        print("start test1")
        browser.get(link)
        browser.find_element(By.CSS_SELECTOR, "#login_link")
        print("finish test1")

    def test_guest_should_see_basket_link_on_the_main_page(self, browser):
        print("start test2")
        browser.get(link)
        browser.find_element(By.CSS_SELECTOR, ".basket-mini .btn-group > a")
        print("finish test2")

We see that in the above example, the browser opened once, and the tests ran one-at-a-time in that browser. We've done that for the sake of an example, but we strongly recommend launching a separate browser copy for each test to improve test stability. Fixtures that require a long launching time and lots of resources (usually, it's about working with databases), may be also called just once within a test run session.

task_list.name: fixtures autouse
task_list.description_text:
Fixture autouse

While describing a fixture, we can indicate an additional parameter autouse=True, which shows that the fixture should be run for each test even without an explicit call: 

test_fixture_autouse.py

import pytest
from selenium import webdriver
from selenium.webdriver.common.by import By

link = "http://selenium1py.pythonanywhere.com/"


@pytest.fixture
def browser():
    print("\nstart browser for test..")
    browser = webdriver.Chrome()
    yield browser
    print("\nquit browser..")
    browser.quit()

@pytest.fixture(autouse=True)
def prepare_data():
    print()
    print("preparing some critical data for every test")


class TestMainPage1():
    def test_guest_should_see_login_link(self, browser):
        # the prepare_data fixture is not passed as a parameter but it's executed anyway
        browser.get(link)
        browser.find_element(By.CSS_SELECTOR, "#login_link")

    def test_guest_should_see_basket_link_on_the_main_page(self, browser):
        browser.get(link)
        browser.find_element(By.CSS_SELECTOR, ".basket-mini .btn-group > a")

Try running that code, and you will see that the data preparation fixture is executed for each test without an explicit call. You need to be careful with this parameter because the fixture is run for all tests. Without an obvious necessity, fixture autouse should be avoided. 

Conclusion

An auxiliary function is a powerful tool that solves numerous problems when working with automated tests. The major advantage is that they can be used in any tests without code duplication. 

We strongly recommend reading additional material on fixtures:

https://habr.com/ru/company/yandex/blog/242795/

https://docs.pytest.org/en/stable/fixture.html

task_list.name: fixtures_task
task_list.description_text:
Task: fixture scope

We have a set of tests that uses several fixtures. Calculate how many smileys will be printed after executing this test class. 

import pytest


@pytest.fixture(scope="class")
def prepare_faces():
    print("^_^", "\n")
    yield
    print(":3", "\n")


@pytest.fixture()
def very_important_fixture():
    print(":)", "\n")


@pytest.fixture(autouse=True)
def print_smiling_faces():
    print(":-Р", "\n")


class TestPrintSmilingFaces():
    def test_first_smiling_faces(self, prepare_faces, very_important_fixture):
        # some assertions

    def test_second_smiling_faces(self, prepare_faces):
        # some assertions

task_list.name: test parametrization
task_list.description_text:
Параметризация тестов

PyTest позволяет запустить один и тот же тест с разными входными параметрами. Для этого используется декоратор @pytest.mark.parametrize(). Наш сайт доступен для разных языков. Напишем тест, который проверит, что для сайта с русским и английским языком будет отображаться ссылка на форму логина. Передадим в наш тест ссылки на русскую и английскую версию главной страницы сайта.

В @pytest.mark.parametrize() нужно передать параметр, который должен изменяться, и список значений параметра. В самом тесте наш параметр тоже нужно передавать в качестве аргумента. Обратите внимание, что внутри декоратора имя параметра оборачивается в кавычки, а в списке аргументов теста кавычки не нужны.

test_fixture7.py: 

import pytest
from selenium import webdriver
from selenium.webdriver.common.by import By

@pytest.fixture(scope="function")
def browser():
    print("\nstart browser for test..")
    browser = webdriver.Chrome()
    yield browser
    print("\nquit browser..")
    browser.quit()

@pytest.mark.parametrize('language', ["ru", "en-gb"])
def test_guest_should_see_login_link(browser, language):
    link = f"http://selenium1py.pythonanywhere.com/{language}/"
    browser.get(link)
    browser.find_element(By.CSS_SELECTOR, "#login_link")

Запустите тест:

pytest -s -v test_fixture7.py

 Вы увидите, что запустятся два теста.  В названии каждого теста в квадратных скобках будет написан параметр, с которым он был запущен. Таким образом мы можем быстро и без дублирования кода увеличить количество проверок для похожих сценариев.

Можно задавать параметризацию также для всего тестового класса, чтобы все тесты в классе запустились с заданными параметрами. В таком случае отметка о параметризации должна быть перед объявлением класса: 

@pytest.mark.parametrize('language', ["ru", "en-gb"])
class TestLogin:
    def test_guest_should_see_login_link(self, browser, language):
        link = f"http://selenium1py.pythonanywhere.com/{language}/"
        browser.get(link)
        browser.find_element(By.CSS_SELECTOR, "#login_link")
        # этот тест запустится 2 раза

    def test_guest_should_see_navbar_element(self, browser, language):
        # этот тест тоже запустится дважды

Дополнительно, полезный туториал из документации: Parametrizing fixtures and test functions

task_list.name: marking tests with pytest
task_list.description_text:
Test marking: part 1

When the number of tests becomes large, it's a good idea to identify them not only by names but also by some other defined categories. For example, we can select a small number of smoke tests, which need to be run after each new commit from the developers, and define the rest as regression tests, which should be run only before the release. Or, we can have tests specific to a certain browser (e.g., Internet Explorer 11), and we want to run them only on that browser. To selectively launch such tests, PyTest uses test marks. To mark tests, you need to write a decorator like @pytest.mark.mark_name, where mark_name  is an arbitrary string.

Let's divide the tests from one of our previous examples into smoke and regression ones.

test_fixture8.py:

import pytest
from selenium import webdriver
from selenium.webdriver.common.by import By

link = "http://selenium1py.pythonanywhere.com/"


@pytest.fixture(scope="function")
def browser():
    print("\nstart browser for test..")
    browser = webdriver.Chrome()
    yield browser
    print("\nquit browser..")
    browser.quit()


class TestMainPage1():

    @pytest.mark.smoke
    def test_guest_should_see_login_link(self, browser):
        browser.get(link)
        browser.find_element(By.CSS_SELECTOR, "#login_link")

    @pytest.mark.regression
    def test_guest_should_see_basket_link_on_the_main_page(self, browser):
        browser.get(link)
        browser.find_element(By.CSS_SELECTOR, ".basket-mini .btn-group > a")

To run a test with a given mark, we need to pass the -m parameter and the required mark in the command line:

pytest -s -v -m smoke test_fixture8.py

If everything is correct, only the test with the smoke mark will be launched.

You will also see a warning:

PytestUnknownMarkWarning: Unknown pytest.mark.smoke - is this a typo?  You can register custom marks to avoid this warning - for details, see https://docs.pytest.org/en/latest/mark.html
    PytestUnknownMarkWarning,

The warning is displayed because the latest versions of PyTest insistently recommend to explicitly register marks before use. That allows avoiding typos – situations where you erroneously used a non-existent test mark and the test ends up being skipped.

Hpw are marks registered?

Create a file pytest.ini in the root directory of your test project and add the following lines to the file:

[pytest]
markers =
    smoke: marker for smoke tests
    regression: marker for regression tests

The text following the ":" sign is a commentary and may be skipped.

Run the tests again:

pytest -s -v -m smoke test_fixture8.py

Now, there should be no warnings.

 

You can also mark a whole test class. In that case, marking will be applied to all test methods included in the class.

task_list.name: marking tests with pytest - inversion
task_list.description_text:
Test marking: part 2

Inversion

To launch all the tests that do not have a given mark, you can use inversion. To run all the tests that are not marked as smoke ones, execute the following command:

pytest -s -v -m "not smoke" test_fixture8.py

Combining tests with different marks

To run tests with different marks, you can use the logical OR operator. Let's launch smoke and regression tests:

pytest -s -v -m "smoke or regression" test_fixture8.py

Choosing tests with several marks

Let's say we have smoke tests that need to be run only for a specific operating system, for example, Windows 10. We'll register the mark win10 in the file pytest.ini and add that mark to one of the tests.

pytest.ini:

[pytest]
markers =
    smoke: marker for smoke tests
    regression: marker for regression tests
    win10

test_fixture81.py:

import pytest
from selenium import webdriver
from selenium.webdriver.common.by import By

link = "http://selenium1py.pythonanywhere.com/"


@pytest.fixture(scope="function")
def browser():
    print("\nstart browser for test..")
    browser = webdriver.Chrome()
    yield browser
    print("\nquit browser..")
    browser.quit()


class TestMainPage1:

    @pytest.mark.smoke
    def test_guest_should_see_login_link(self, browser):
        browser.get(link)
        browser.find_element(By.CSS_SELECTOR, "#login_link")

    @pytest.mark.smoke
    @pytest.mark.win10
    def test_guest_should_see_basket_link_on_the_main_page(self, browser):
        browser.get(link)
        browser.find_element(By.CSS_SELECTOR, ".basket-mini .btn-group > a")

To launch only the smoke tests for Windows 10, we need to use the logical AND operator:

pytest -s -v -m "smoke and win10" test_fixture81.py

The test_guest_should_see_basket_link_on_the_main_page test will be launched.

task_list.name: xfail - expecting test to fail
task_list.description_text:
XFail: marking tests expected to fail

Mark a test as failing

Now, let's add a new test to our test class – it checks for the "Favorite" button:

def test_guest_should_see_search_button_on_the_main_page(self, browser): 
     browser.get(link)
     browser.find_element(By.CSS_SELECTOR, "button.favorite")

Let's assume that such a button does exist but has disappeared because of code changes. While developers are fixing the bug, we want to make sure that all our tests pass successively but the failing test gets a special mark so that we don't forget about it. We'll add the @pytest.mark.xfail mark for the failing test.

test_fixture10.py:

import pytest
from selenium import webdriver
from selenium.webdriver.common.by import By

link = "http://selenium1py.pythonanywhere.com/"


@pytest.fixture(scope="function")
def browser():
    print("\nstart browser for test..")
    browser = webdriver.Chrome()
    yield browser
    print("\nquit browser..")
    browser.quit()


class TestMainPage1():

    def test_guest_should_see_login_link(self, browser):
        browser.get(link)
        browser.find_element(By.CSS_SELECTOR, "#login_link")

    def test_guest_should_see_basket_link_on_the_main_page(self, browser):
        browser.get(link)
        browser.find_element(By.CSS_SELECTOR, ".basket-mini .btn-group > a")

    @pytest.mark.xfail
    def test_guest_should_see_search_button_on_the_main_page(self, browser):
        browser.get(link)
        browser.find_element(By.CSS_SELECTOR, "button.favorite")

Let's run our tests:

pytest -v test_fixture10.py

Now, the failed test is marked xfail, but the result of running all tests is successful:

When the bug gets fixed, we'll see it, as our test will be marked XPASS (“unexpectedly passing”). Then, the xfail mark for the test may be deleted. Actually, you can add the reason parameter to the xfail mark. To see the message in the console, add the pytest -rx parameter at launch time.

test_fixture10a.py:

import pytest
from selenium import webdriver
from selenium.webdriver.common.by import By

link = "http://selenium1py.pythonanywhere.com/"


@pytest.fixture(scope="function")
def browser():
    print("\nstart browser for test..")
    browser = webdriver.Chrome()
    yield browser
    print("\nquit browser..")
    browser.quit()


class TestMainPage1():

    def test_guest_should_see_login_link(self, browser):
        browser.get(link)
        browser.find_element(By.CSS_SELECTOR, "#login_link")

    def test_guest_should_see_basket_link_on_the_main_page(self, browser):
        browser.get(link)
        browser.find_element(By.CSS_SELECTOR, ".basket-mini .btn-group > a")

    @pytest.mark.xfail(reason="fixing this bug right now")
    def test_guest_should_see_search_button_on_the_main_page(self, browser):
        browser.get(link)
        browser.find_element(By.CSS_SELECTOR, "button.favorite")

Let's run our tests:

pytest -rx -v test_fixture10a.py

 

Compare the test results for both cases.

XPASS tests

Let's change the selector in the latter test so that the test would pass.

test_fixture10b.py:

import pytest
from selenium import webdriver
from selenium.webdriver.common.by import By

link = "http://selenium1py.pythonanywhere.com/"


@pytest.fixture(scope="function")
def browser():
    print("\nstart browser for test..")
    browser = webdriver.Chrome()
    yield browser
    print("\nquit browser..")
    browser.quit()


class TestMainPage1():

    def test_guest_should_see_login_link(self, browser):
        browser.get(link)
        browser.find_element(By.CSS_SELECTOR, "#login_link")

    def test_guest_should_see_basket_link_on_the_main_page(self, browser):
        browser.get(link)
        browser.find_element(By.CSS_SELECTOR, ".basket-mini .btn-group > a")

    @pytest.mark.xfail(reason="fixing this bug right now")
    def test_guest_should_see_search_button_on_the_main_page(self, browser):
        browser.get(link)
        browser.find_element(By.CSS_SELECTOR, "input.btn.btn-default")

Run the tests. We've added the X symbol to the -r parameter to get detailed information on XPASS tests:

pytest -rX -v test_fixture10b.py

See the report: 

You can find additional information on using these marks in the documentation: Skip and xfail: dealing with tests that cannot succeed.  There you can find many interesting features: for example, how to skip a test only when a certain condition is met, how to make an unexpectedly passed xfailed test appear red in the report, etc.

task_list.name: task_running_test
task_list.description_text:
Task: running tests

In this task, you need to figure out the intricacies of test marking. We have a file with tests that have been marked for different launching situations.

test_task_run_1.py:

import pytest


class TestMainPage():
    # номер 1
    @pytest.mark.xfail
    @pytest.mark.smoke
    def test_guest_can_login(self, browser):
        assert True

    # номер 2
    @pytest.mark.regression
    def test_guest_can_add_book_from_catalog_to_basket(self, browser):
        assert True


class TestBasket():
    # номер 3
    @pytest.mark.skip(reason="not implemented yet")
    @pytest.mark.smoke
    def test_guest_can_go_to_payment_page(self, browser):
        assert True

    # номер 4
    @pytest.mark.smoke
    def test_guest_can_see_total_price(self, browser):
        assert True


@pytest.mark.skip
class TestBookPage():
    # номер 5
    @pytest.mark.smoke
    def test_guest_can_add_book_to_basket(self, browser):
        assert True

    # номер 6
    @pytest.mark.regression
    def test_guest_can_see_book_price(self, browser):
        assert True


# номер 7
@pytest.mark.beta_users
@pytest.mark.smoke
def test_guest_can_open_gadget_catalogue(browser):
    assert True

Below, identify the test methods that will be found and executed by PyTest if we run the following command: 

pytest -v -m "smoke and not beta_users" test_task_run_1.py

task_list.name: test configuration
task_list.description_text:
Conftest.py — test configuration

We've previously added the browser fixture, which creates a copy of the browser for tests in a given file. When we have more than one test file, we need to describe the fixture in each file. That's very inconvenient. Frequently used fixtures as well as global settings should be stored in the conftest.py file, which must be located in the upper-level directory of your project with the tests. We can also create additional conftest.py files in other directories, but then the settings in those files will be applied only to the tests in subdirectories.

Let's create a conftest.py file in the root directory of our test project and move the browser fixture there. See how much more concise the file with tests looks now.

conftest.py:

import pytest
from selenium import webdriver
from selenium.webdriver.common.by import By

@pytest.fixture(scope="function")
def browser():
    print("\nstart browser for test..")
    browser = webdriver.Chrome()
    yield browser
    print("\nquit browser..")
    browser.quit()

Now, no matter how many files with tests we create, the tests will have access to the browser fixture. The fixture is passed to the test method as an argument. Thus, you can conveniently reuse the same auxiliary functions in different project parts.


test_conftest.py:

from selenium.webdriver.common.by import By

link = "http://selenium1py.pythonanywhere.com/"

def test_guest_should_see_login_link(browser):
    browser.get(link)
    browser.find_element(By.CSS_SELECTOR, "#login_link")

VERY IMPORTANT! 

You need to be aware of one important feature of configuration files' behavior. PyTest automatically finds and loads conftest.py files that are located in the directory with the tests. If you keep all your course scripts in one directory, be cautious and make sure to avoid the situation where you run the tests from the tests folder:

tests/
├── conftest.py
├── subfolder
│   └── conftest.py
│   └── test_abs.py

Avoid that!

In such a case, BOTH conftest.py files are applied, which might result in unpredictable errors and conflicts.  

This way we can redefine different fixtures, but within our course, we recommend sticking to one file per project/task and storing them horizontally, like this:: 

selenium_course_solutions/
├── section3
│   └── conftest.py
│   └── test_languages.py
├── section4 
│   └── conftest.py
│   └── test_main_page.py

Correct!

Be cautious and make sure not to have different conftest in nested directories, especially when you download and check your group mates' tasks.

Override a fixture on a folder (conftest) level

task_list.name: test parametrization
task_list.description_text:
Test parametrization

PyTest allows running the same test with different input parameters. To do that, use the @pytest.mark.parametrize() decorator. Our site is available in various languages. Let's write a test that checks that the Russian- and English-language site displays a link to the log-in form. We'll pass the links to the Russian and English versions of our site's front page to our tests.

We need to pass the parameter that may change and the list of parameter values to @pytest.mark.parametrize(). In the test itself, the parameter should also be passed as an argument. Notice that inside the decorator, the name of the parameter is put in quotes, while the list of test arguments does not require quotes.

test_fixture7.py: 

import pytest
from selenium import webdriver
from selenium.webdriver.common.by import By

@pytest.fixture(scope="function")
def browser():
    print("\nstart browser for test..")
    browser = webdriver.Chrome()
    yield browser
    print("\nquit browser..")
    browser.quit()

@pytest.mark.parametrize('language', ["ru", "en-gb"])
def test_guest_should_see_login_link(browser, language):
    link = f"http://selenium1py.pythonanywhere.com/{language}/"
    browser.get(link)
    browser.find_element(By.CSS_SELECTOR, "#login_link")

Let's run the test:

pytest -s -v test_fixture7.py

You'll see that two tests have been started. The name of each test contains the used parameter in square brackets. Thus, we can quickly and without code duplication increase the number of checks for similar scenarios.

We can also use parametrization for the whole test class so that all the tests in the class would run with the set parameters. In that case, the parametrization mark must precede the declaration of the class: 

@pytest.mark.parametrize('language', ["ru", "en-gb"])
class TestLogin:
    def test_guest_should_see_login_link(self, browser, language):
        link = f"http://selenium1py.pythonanywhere.com/{language}/"
        browser.get(link)
        browser.find_element(By.CSS_SELECTOR, "#login_link")
        # this test will be launched 2 times

    def test_guest_should_see_navbar_element(self, browser, language):
        #this test will be launched 2 times

Here's a helpful additional tutorial from the documentation: Parametrizing fixtures and test functions.

task_list.name: task_parametrization
task_list.description_text:
Задание: параметризация тестов

Инопланетяне оставляют загадочные сообщения на Stepik в фидбеке задач на правильное решение. Мы смогли локализовать несколько url-адресов задач, где появляются кусочки сообщений. Ваша задача — реализовать автотест со следующим сценарием действий: 

  • открыть страницу 
  • авторизоваться на странице со своим логином и паролем (см. предыдущий шаг)
  • ввести правильный ответ (поле перед вводом должно быть пустым)
  • нажать кнопку "Отправить" 
  • дождаться фидбека о том, что ответ правильный 
  • проверить, что текст в опциональном фидбеке полностью совпадает с "Correct!"

Опциональный фидбек — это текст в черном поле, как показано на скриншоте: 

![img.png](img.png)

Правильным ответом на задачу в заданных шагах является число:


import time
import math

answer = math.log(int(time.time()))

Используйте маркировку pytest для параметризации и передайте в тест список ссылок в качестве параметров:
